awd_titl_txt: RTG: Algebraic Topology and Its Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Recently, algebraic topology has found a number of applications within mathematics and beyond. For example, topology provided powerful new methods for detecting and describing shape and structure in complex and high-dimensional data. This award supports the Research Training Group in Algebraic Topology and its Applications at Ohio State University. This work will be performed in a highly collaborative and active interdisciplinary research environment that has recently emerged, involving investigators from the Departments of Mathematics and Computer Science & Engineering. The main objective of the project is to provide early-stage mathematicians and computer scientists with opportunities to learn about both theoretical and applied aspects of topology and related fields. Exposure to these topics will allow students and junior faculty to move fluently across a range of research topics, to enter research communities in traditional core areas, and to work in new interdisciplinary directions.

This award supports postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate researchers studying such topology-related fields as geometric group theory, metric geometry, computational geometry and topology, knot theory, and stochastic topology. The award also supports the development of new courses, as well as working groups, seminars, and workshops in these areas. At the heart of the project is an emphasis on mentoring at all levels. The program also places a strong emphasis on developing writing and communication skills, particularly for postdoctoral researchers and graduate students involved in the research group.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp
RES TRAINING GROUPS IN THE MATH SCIENCES

por.por_cntn:
This project supported a Research Training Group (RTG) in algebraic topology and its applications. The main purpose of the project was in training PhD students and postdoctoral researchers. The scientific focus was in topology, broadly construed, including: geometric group theory, homotopy theory, topological data analysis, quantitative topology, stochastic topology, knot theory, computational topology, and more. These early-career researchers worked in vertically integrated groups, and together with faculty mentors produced a large body of collaborative work. The project was interdisciplinary by its nature, and was hosted jointly between the Departments of Mathematics and Computer Science & Engineering.

Activity supported by the project including the following.

  • The award provided a number of semester-long fellowships to PhD students, to support time for research and thesis writing.
  • The award sponsored a number of 1-3 year postdoctoral fellowships.  
  • The award sponsored a summer program, providing undergraduate researchers research experiences studiying knots and links. This resulted in a number of undergraduate publications.
  • For the duration of the award, Ohio State's Department of Mathematics hosted a "Topology, geometry, and data analysis (TGDA)" Seminar, meeting most weeks during the academic year.
  • Ohio State also hosted "TGDA mini-courses", supported by this award, where an expert would visit for roughly a week and deliver a focused lecture series. These lectures were often accompanied by opportunities for students and postdocs to meet with the visiting senior researcher in informal settings.
  • The award sponsored the travel of participants from Ohio State to a number of conferences and workshops, including some semester-long special programs.
  • A supplement to the award supported a "RTG program meeting": in November 2018. At this meeting, RTG PIs and other key program contributors convened in Alexandria, VA to discuss important issues relevant to both RTG programs and the broader mathematics community. Programs shared effective practices, discussed challenges, and offered recommendations to help support current and future PIs. Presentations and breakout sessions focused on achievements and challenges in the areas of vertically-integrated training, broadening participation, RTG innovations, evaluating program impact, and program sustainability.

PhD students and postdoctoral researchers sponsored by this award have gone on to careers in academia, industry, and government work. The award had a measurable impact on the training of early-career researchers in topology and its applications.


Last Modified: 09/28/2024
Modified by: Matthew K Kahle
